tn.text: one years** - "31 years" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
This is the name of a woman. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of a man. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of a town in Judah. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: He did what was right in the eyes of Yahweh
tn.text: Here "eyes" represents Yahweh's thoughts or what he considered about something. AT: "He did what Yahweh considered to be right" or "He did what was right according to Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: He walked in all the way of David his ancestor
tn.text: "He walked in all the ways of David his ancestor" Josiah behaving as David did is spoken of as if he walked on the same road or way as David. AT: "He lived the way David his ancestor had lived" or "He followed the example of David his ancestor" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: he did not turn away either to the right or to the left
tn.text: To fully obey Yahweh is spoken of as if a person were on the correct road and never turned from it. AT: "he did not do anything that would displease Yahweh" or "he fully obeyed all the laws of Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
If your language has a way to mark the beginning of a new part of the story, consider using it here.
"Eighteenth" is the ordinal form of 18. AT: "the 18th year" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_ordinal]])
These are men's names. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: house of Yahweh ... in the temple
tn.text: Here "house of Yahweh" and "temple" mean the same thing.
The phrase "Go up" is used because Yahweh's temple was higher in elevation than where King Josiah was located. AT: "Go to Hilkiah"

tn.ref: that has been brought into the house of Yahweh, which the temple guards have gathered from the people
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "that the temple guards who gathered the money from the people brought into the temple of Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Let it be given into the hand of the workmen
tn.text: Here "hand" represents the workmen as a whole. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Tell Hilkiah to give the money to the workmen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The message from King Josiah to Hilkiah, the high priest, continues.

tn.ref: Let them give money ... was given to them ... because they handled
tn.text: Here "them" and "they" refer to the workmen who are in charge of the house of Yahweh in [[:en:bible:notes:2ki:22:03|22:5]].

tn.ref: the carpenters, the builders, and the masons
tn.text: These are the same as the workmen who are in the house of Yahweh in [[:en:bible:notes:2ki:22:03|22:5]]. Here the workers are described in more detail.
workers who build with wood
workers who build with stone

tn.ref: no accounting was required for the money that was given to them
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "the workmen who were in charge did not have to report how they used the money that the temple guards gave them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"because they used the money honestly"
This is the name of a man. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:2ki:18:16|18:18]].
Most likely these laws were written on a scroll rather than in a book.

tn.ref: given it into the hand of the workmen
tn.text: Here "hand" represents the workmen as a whole. AT: "given it to the workmen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
If your language has a way to mark the beginning of a new part of the story, consider using it here.

tn.ref: had heard the words of the law
tn.text: Here "words" represents the message of the law. AT: "had heard the laws that were written in the book" or "had heard the laws that were written in the scroll" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is a symbolic action that indicates intense grief or sadness. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
These are names of men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
It is made clear in 22:14 that the men would consult Yahweh by going to the prophetess of Yahweh to determine his will.
to go to someone to ask for advice

tn.ref: the words of this book that has been found
tn.text: Here "words" represents the laws. This can be stated in active form. AT: "the laws in this book that Hilkiah has found" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: For great is the anger of Yahweh that has been kindled against us
tn.text: Yahweh's anger is spoken of as if it was a fire that was lit. AT: "For Yahweh is very angry with us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: all that was written concerning us
tn.text: This refers to the law that was given to Israel.  This can be stated in active form. AT: "all that Moses wrote in the law that we should do" or "all the laws that God gave through Moses to the people of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This is a woman's name. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
These are men's names. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Possible meanings are 1) the person who took care of the clothing that priests wore in the temple or 2) the person who took care of the king's clothing.

tn.ref: she lived in Jerusalem in the second quarter
tn.text: Here "second quarter" refers to the new part of the city that was built on the north side of Jerusalem. Also, "second" is the ordinal form of 2. AT: "she lived in Jerusalem in the new part of the city" or "she lived in the new part of Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_ordinal]])

tn.ref: the man who sent you to me
tn.text: Here "the man" refers to King Josiah.

tn.ref: I will bring disaster to this place and to its inhabitants
tn.text: Yahweh causing terrible things to happen is spoken of as if "disaster" were an object that he could bring to a place. AT: "I will cause terrible things to happen to this place and to those who live there" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This refers to the city of Jerusalem which represents the whole land of Judah. AT: "to Jerusalem" or "to Judah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
The message Yahweh sent to King Josiah through Huldah, the prophetess, continues.

tn.ref: my anger has been kindled against this place, and it will not be extinguished
tn.text: Yahweh becoming very angry is spoken of as if his anger were a fire that was lit and could not be put out. AT: "my anger against this place is like a fire that cannot be put out" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "place" represents the people who live in Jerusalem and Judah. AT: "these people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: About the words that you heard
tn.text: Here "words" represents the message that Huldah just spoke. AT: "About the message that you heard" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Here "heart" represents a person's inner being. To feel sorry is spoken of as if the heart were tender. AT: "because you felt sorry" or "because you repented" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: that they would become a desolation and a curse
tn.text: The abstract nouns "desolation" and "curse" can be stated as an adjective and a verb. AT: "that I would curse them and cause the land to be desolate" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
This is a symbolic action that indicates intense grief or sadness. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])

tn.ref: this is the declaration of Yahweh
tn.text: Here Yahweh speaks about himself in the third person. It can be stated in first person. AT: "this is what I declare" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
This is the end of the message from Yahweh to King Josiah through the prophetess Huldah.

tn.ref: See, I will gather you to your ancestors; you will be gathered to your grave in peace
tn.text: Both statements mean basically the same thing. They are polite ways of saying he will die. AT: "Listen, I will allow you to die peacefully" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

Here "eyes" represents the whole person. And, "will not see" represents not experiencing something. AT: "and you will not experience" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: the disaster that I will bring upon this place
tn.text: Yahweh causing terrible things to happen is spoken of as if "disaster" were an object that Yahweh would bring to a place. AT: "the terrible things I will cause to happen in this place" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
